intro: Oskampia scandens, commonly known as the climbing oskampia, is a flowering plant belonging to the family Apiaceae. It is characterized by its slender, climbing stems and compound leaves with finely divided leaflets. The plant produces small, clustered flowers that are typically white or pale yellow, which bloom in late spring to early summer. Oskampia scandens is native to certain regions of Europe and is often found in moist, woodland habitats. Its botanical features make it a distinctive member of the carrot family, though it is less commonly cultivated than other members.
